learning_outcomes.description: Describe and critique the principles and processes of health policy development and implementation.

Critically analyse strengths in the Australian health policy in relation to a selected health condition by examining health data, relevant policy documents, and the evidence base for policy responses.
Collect and critically appraise literature and policy responses pertaining to health issues within vulnerable populations and make recommendations to respond to areas of unmet need.
Identify and analyse the role of stakeholders including government, community partners and others in the development and implementation of health policy.
Demonstrate effective written communication skills, including adherence to genre and referencing guidelines.
Demonstrate critical thinking skills, particularly regarding the use of generative artificial intelligence tools.

assessments.task_description:
Students will develop a background paper (a concise critical summary) using scientific evidence to identify and describe a contemporary Australian health issue for a vulnerable population. It will include information on the impact of the health condition on the population; the determinants of differences in health; the barriers to accessing support and care; the need for appropriate policy to address the identified health issue.

Further information on assessment tasks will be provided on Blackboard and during teaching activities.

In-person peer review will be undertaken in class in Week 13 (25 May 2026). If students cannot attend this workshop, they can still pass the hurdle by providing written feedback on a policy brief draft at a later date. However, they will not receive any feedback on their own policy brief draft if they do not attend the workshop.
assessments.task_description:
Drawing on knowledge gained throughout the course students will present their final policy brief which includes the incorporation of policy recommendations for their selected health issue and population group, building on the previous three assessment tasks. The assignment will involve the submission of a 2 page written policy brief. It is expected that the brief will integrate feedback and critique provided on earlier assessment tasks.

Students will provide each other with written feedback on a draft of the policy brief in class following a provided template, one week before the submission date. Feedback must be provided to pass the pass/fail hurdle. The final policy brief, marked by teaching staff, determines the grade received for the 30% weighting.

Further information on assessment tasks will be provided on Blackboard and during teaching activities.
